tit.e: The Matsui Clan
The Matsui Clan
The Matsui Clan

sen.j: 松井氏（まついし）は日本の氏族の一つ。
sen.e: The Matsui clan is a Japanese clan.
The Matsui clan was a Japanese clan.
The Matsui clan was a Japanese clan.

sen.j: 清和源氏を祖とする松井氏 ； 清和源氏為義流の源維義（松井冠者）を祖とする松井氏と、源満政を祖とする松井氏がある。
sen.e: The clan has three branches: one that originated from the Seiwa-Genji (Seiwa Gen clan), one branch whose forefather was MINAMOTO no Koreyoshi (kaja MATSUI) of the Tameyoshi line who originated from the Seiwa-Genji (Seiwa Gen clan), and one whose forefather was MINAMOTO no Mitsumasa.

The clan had three branches; one that originated from Seiwa-Genji (Minamoto clan); one that originated from MINAMOTO no Koreyoshi (Kanja MATSUI) who was from the Tameyoshi line of Seiwa-Genji; and one that originated from MINAMOTO no Mitsumasa.
sen.cmt: 用語の統一。スタイルの統一。
sen.e: The clan had three branches; one that originated from Seiwa-Genji (Minamoto clan); one that originated from MINAMOTO no Koreyoshi (Kanja MATSUI) who was from the Tameyoshi line of Seiwa-Genji; and one that originated from MINAMOTO no Mitsumasa.

sen.j: 源維義流には三河松井氏（松井松平家）・遠江松井氏がある。
sen.e: MINAMOTO no Koreyoshi line includes the Mikawa Matsui clan (Matsui Matsudaira family) and the Totomi MATSUI clan.
MINAMOTO no Koreyoshi line included the Mikawa Matsui clan (Matsui Matsudaira family) and the Totomi Matsui clan.
MINAMOTO no Koreyoshi line included the Mikawa Matsui clan (Matsui Matsudaira family) and the Totomi Matsui clan.

sen.j: 室町将軍家の御家人の松井氏も同流という。
sen.e: Another branch from the MINAMOTO no Koreyoshi line was the Muromachi shogunate family and served as gokenin (an immediate vassal of the shogunate in the Kamakura and Muromachi throughout the Edo period).
It has been said that the Matsui clan that served the Muromachi shogunate as Gokenin (an immediate vassal of the shogunate) originated from the MINAMOTO no Koreyoshi line as well.
sen.cmt: わかりやすくしました。
sen.e: It has been said that the Matsui clan that served the Muromachi shogunate as Gokenin (an immediate vassal of the shogunate) originated from the MINAMOTO no Koreyoshi line as well.

sen.j: 江戸時代には、肥後熊本藩主細川氏の筆頭家老で実質の八代城主になった。
sen.e: During the Edo period, they served as the Hitto karo (the head of chief retainers) of the HOSOKAWA clan, the lord of Kumamoto domain in Higo Province, and the lord of Yatsushiro Castle.
In the Edo period, they served the lord of the Kumamoto Domain in Higo Province, the Hosokawa clan as Hittokaro (head of chief retainers), and became the lord of Yatsushiro-jo Castle.
sen.cmt: 用語の統一。わかりやすくしました。
sen.e: In the Edo period, they served the lord of the Kumamoto Domain in Higo Province, the Hosokawa clan as Hittokaro (head of chief retainers), and became the lord of Yatsushiro-jo Castle.

sen.j: 下記の項目松井氏（清和源氏為義流）に説明がある。
sen.e: The section below further explains the Tameyoshi line, which originated from the Seiwa-Genji.
The section below further explains the Tameyoshi line of the Seiwa-Genji.
The section below further explains the Tameyoshi line of the Seiwa-Genji.

sen.j: 山城松井氏 ； 山城国松井に移住した渡来系で百済人と云う松井氏。
sen.e: The Yamashiro Matsui clan; the Matsui clan are said to be immigrants from the ancient Korean kingdom (Paekche or Kudara) who moved to Matsui in the Yamashiro County.
The Yamashiro Matsui clan: It is said that this Matsui clan immigrated from Kudara (Baekche, Korea) into Matsui in the Yamashiro Province.
The Yamashiro Matsui clan: It is said that this Matsui clan immigrated from Kudara (Baekche, Korea) into Matsui in the Yamashiro Province.

sen.j: 続日本紀によれば、天平宝字5年に松井連を朝廷より下賜された。
sen.e: According to "Shoku Nihongi" (Chronicle of Japan Continued), they were granted the title MATSUI no muraji (MATSUI clan) from the Imperial Court in 753.
sen.cmt: 西暦は以下のサイトから計算しました。http://koyomi.vis.ne.jp/9reki/otonidx08c.htm
sen.e: According to "Shoku Nihongi" (Chronicle of Japan Continued), they were given the hereditary title MATSUI no Muraji by the Imperial Court in 761.
sen.cmt: 「天平宝字5年」は761年（平楽寺書店『東方年表』）
sen.e: According to "Shoku Nihongi" (Chronicle of Japan Continued), they were given the hereditary title MATSUI no Muraji by the Imperial Court in 761.

sen.j: また綴喜郡松井村などが見える。
sen.e: Their surname Matsui can be traced to Matsui village, or present day Tsuzuki County, located in the former Yamashiro County.
According the record, there had been Matsui-mura village, Tsuzuki-no-kori County.
sen.cmt: オリジナルに近く、わかりやすくしました。
sen.e: According the record, there had been Matsui-mura village, Tsuzuki-no-kori County.

sen.j: ほかに太平記収載の山城国住人・松井蔵人。
sen.e: Kurondo MATSUI, who resided in the Yamashiro County and appears in "Taiheiki" (The Record of the Great Peace) is also thought to be from this clan.
Kurondo MATSUI, who resided in the Yamashiro Province and appears in "Taiheiki" (The Record of the Great Peace) is also thought to be from this clan.
Kurondo MATSUI, who resided in the Yamashiro Province and appears in "Taiheiki" (The Record of the Great Peace) is also thought to be from this clan.

sen.j: 同国の松井氏には清和源氏出身もある（上記の流れ）。
sen.e: Some Matsui clans from the same county originate from the Seiwa-Genji.
In the same province, there were also other Matsui clans that originated from Seiwa-Genji.
sen.cmt: 用語の統一。わかりやすくしました。
sen.e: In the same province, there were also other Matsui clans that originated from Seiwa-Genji.

sen.j: 美濃松井氏 ； 室町・戦国期に多藝郡大墳城主として松井九郎直清が割拠。
sen.e: The Mino MATSUI clan; Kuro Naokiyo MATSUI defended the local authority as the lord of Otsuka-jo castle in Taki County during the Moromachi period and Sengoku period (period of Warring States).
The Mino MATSUI clan: Among them, Kuro Naokiyo MATSUI is known as the lord of Otsuka-jo Castle in Taki County during the Muromachi period and the Sengoku period (Period of Warring States).
sen.cmt: 「lord」という説明だけで「割拠」の意味になります。用語の統一。わかりやすくしました。
sen.e: The Mino MATSUI clan: Among them, Kuro Naokiyo MATSUI is known as the lord of Otsuka-jo Castle in Taki County during the Muromachi period and the Sengoku period (Period of Warring States).

sen.j: 日向松井氏 ； 日向国宮崎郡の松井氏。
sen.e: The Hyuga Matsui clan; the Matsui clan in the Miyazaki County of Hyuga Province.
The Hyuga Matsui clan: they were active in the Miyazaki County of Hyuga Province.
sen.cmt: わかりやすくしました。
sen.e: The Hyuga Matsui clan: they were active in the Miyazaki County of Hyuga Province.

sen.j: また松井儀成は、私財を投じて用水建設のため測量をなして、藩に建議。
sen.e: Yoshinari MATSUI from the clan made surveys and submitted a proposal for the construction of irrigation canals at his own expense.
Yoshinari MATSUI from the clan made surveys for the irrigational canals at his own expense, and submitted a proposal for the construction of canals to the administration of the domain..
sen.cmt: わかりやすくしました。
sen.e: Yoshinari MATSUI from the clan made surveys for the irrigational canals at his own expense, and submitted a proposal for the construction of canals to the administration of the domain..

sen.j: これが実現して200町歩もの農地が恩恵を受ける。
sen.e: This proposal was executed and 200 chobu (hectares) of agricultural land benefited from his project.
This proposal was executed and 200 chobu (hectares) of agricultural land benefited from his project.
This proposal was executed and 200 chobu (hectares) of agricultural land benefited from his project.

sen.j: 金具師松井氏 ； 金具師・松井弥三郎が豊臣秀吉から200石の知行を受け、徳川家康の大御所時代に駿河国駿府に屋敷をたまわり100石を給せられた。
sen.e: The MATSUI clan of the chaser: the chaser Yasaburo MATSUI received 200 koku of chigyo (enfeoffment) from Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI and a residence as well as 100 koku were awarded in Sunpu of the Suruga Province during the Ogosho period of Ieyasu TOKUGAWA.

The chaser Matsui clan: a chaser Yasaburo MATSUI was given chigyo (enfeoffment) 200 koku (36.078 cubic meters of rice) by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, and later, he was given a residence in Sunpu, Suruga Province as well as 100 koku (18.039 cubic meters of rice) by Ieyasu TOKUGAWA who had already retired at that time.
sen.cmt: わかりやすくしました
sen.e: The chaser Matsui clan: a chaser Yasaburo MATSUI was given chigyo (enfeoffment) 200 koku (36.078 cubic meters of rice) by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, and later, he was given a residence in Sunpu, Suruga Province as well as 100 koku (18.039 cubic meters of rice) by Ieyasu TOKUGAWA who had already retired at that time.

sen.j: 土器大工松井氏 ； 松井弥右衛門、天正年間に岡崎城主・徳川家康に召し出されて、御切り米5俵2人扶持を給せられる。
sen.e: The Matsui clan of the earthenware maker; Yaemon MATSUI was summoned by Ieyasu TOKUGAWA and awarded with five bales (a traditional unit for rice, which is 60 kilograms) and Futari fuchi (the equivalent of an annual two-man rice stipend).

The earthenware maker Matsui clan: Yaemon MATSUI served Ieyasu TOKUGAWA who was the lord of Okazaki-jo Castle in the Tensho era and was given five bales (a traditional unit for rice, which is 60 kilograms) and Futari fuchi (the equivalent of an annual two-man rice stipend).

The earthenware maker Matsui clan: Yaemon MATSUI served Ieyasu TOKUGAWA who was the lord of Okazaki-jo Castle in the Tensho era and was given five bales (a traditional unit for rice, which is 60 kilograms) and Futari fuchi (the equivalent of an annual two-man rice stipend).

sen.j: 江戸入国に随従して、土器御用仰せ付け連綿の家柄となる。
sen.e: He obeyed the Edo shogunate and his family line became the earthenware maker given hereditary appointment to the shogunate.
He followed Ieyasu to Edo, after that, his family became the earthenware maker patronized by the Tokugawa Shogunate.
He followed Ieyasu to Edo, after that, his family became the earthenware maker patronized by the Tokugawa Shogunate.

sen.j: 襲名を新左衛門と云う。
sen.e: Yaemon MATSUI was bestowed the ancestral name of Shinzaemon.
The clan had its hereditary name "Shinzaemon."
sen.cmt: わかりやすくしました。
sen.e: The clan had its hereditary name "Shinzaemon."

sen.j: 丹波松井氏 ； 管領・細川氏の重臣・松井氏。
sen.e: Tanba Matsui clan; the Matsui clan that served as kanrei (shogunal deputy) Hosokawa clan's chief retainer
Tanba Matsui clan: They served Kanrei (shogunal deputy) the Hosokawa clan as a chief retainer.
sen.cmt: わかりやすくしました。
sen.e: Tanba Matsui clan: They served Kanrei (shogunal deputy) the Hosokawa clan as a chief retainer.

sen.j: 清和源氏・源維義（松井冠者）を祖とする松井氏の一系統。
sen.e: One of the family lines of the Matsui clan whose forefather was MINAMOTO no Koreyoshi (kaja MATSUI) from Seiwa-Genji.
They were a branch originated from MINAMOTO no Koreyoshi (Kanja MATSUI) of Seiwa-Genji.
sen.cmt: わかりやすくしました。
sen.e: They were a branch originated from MINAMOTO no Koreyoshi (Kanja MATSUI) of Seiwa-Genji.

sen.j: 戦国期に丹波国竹野郡に松井佐渡守が割拠していた。
sen.e: MATSUI, Sado no kami defended the local authority in Takano County in Tanba Province during the Sengoku period.
Among them, MATSUI Sado no kami is known as the lord of Takeno County in Tanba Province in the Sengoku period.
sen.cmt: わかりやすくしました。
sen.e: Among them, MATSUI Sado no kami is known as the lord of Takeno County in Tanba Province in the Sengoku period.

sen.j: 尼子家臣松井氏 ； 戦国大名・尼子氏家臣の松井氏。
sen.e: The Matsui clan as vassals of the AMAKO family; the Matsui clan who served as the vassal of the Amako family as daimyo (Japanese territorial lord) in the Sengoku period.
The Matsui clan as vassals of the AMAKO family: the Matsui clan which served Sengoku daimyo (Japanese territorial lord in the Sengoku period) the Amako family as vassals in the Sengoku period.
The Matsui clan as vassals of the AMAKO family: the Matsui clan which served Sengoku daimyo (Japanese territorial lord in the Sengoku period) the Amako family as vassals in the Sengoku period.

sen.j: 厳島神官松井氏 ； 周防国厳島神社の神官（祝詞職）の松井氏。
sen.e: The Matsui clan as priests of the Itsukushima-jinja Shrine; the Matsui clan who served as Shinto priests of the Itsukushima-Jinja Shrine in Suo Province.
The Matsui clan as priests of the Itsukushima-jinja Shrine: They served as Shinto priests of the Itsukushima-Jinja Shrine in Suo Province.
The Matsui clan as priests of the Itsukushima-jinja Shrine: They served as Shinto priests of the Itsukushima-Jinja Shrine in Suo Province.

sen.j: 川越藩重臣松井氏 ； 武蔵国川越藩主松平氏の城代家老・筆頭家老であった松井氏。
sen.e: The Matsui clan as senior vassals of the Kawagoe-Domain the Matsui clan who used to be Jodaigaro (chief counselor of a castle) and Hitto karo (the head of chief retainers) of the Matsudaira clan, the lord of the Kawagoe Domain in Musashi Province.

The Matsui clan as senior vassals of the Kawagoe-Domain: They served the lord of the Kawagoe Domain in Musashi Province the Matsudaira clan as Jodaigaro (chief counselor of a castle) and Hittokaro (the head of chief retainers).

The Matsui clan as senior vassals of the Kawagoe-Domain: They served the lord of the Kawagoe Domain in Musashi Province the Matsudaira clan as Jodaigaro (chief counselor of a castle) and Hittokaro (the head of chief retainers).

sen.j: 藩主は松井姓松平氏。
sen.e: The lord was the Matsui clan of the Matsui family
The lord was the Matsui clan of the Matsui family
The lord was the Matsui clan of the Matsui family

sen.j: 越後長岡藩の家臣団牧野氏(2) ； 三河国宝飯郡の国人から近世大名となった藩主牧野氏から牧野姓を賜姓され、牧野姓に改姓した。
sen.e: The Makino clan as vassals of the Echigo-Nagaoka domain; bestowed the Makino surname from the lord of Nagaoka domain Makino clan, who was kokujin of the Hoi County in Mikawa Province but later on became kinsei (early modern) daimyo.

The Makino clan as vassals of the Echigo-Nagaoka Domain: They were bestowed the surname "Makino" by the lord of Nagaoka Domain the Makino clan which had grown from Kokujin (a governor of county) of Hoi County in Mikawa Province to Kinsei Daimyo (feudal lord of the Edo period).
sen.cmt: 用語の統一。わかりやすくしました。（2）はWebを確認してもなかったので訳しておりません。
sen.e: The Makino clan as vassals of the Echigo-Nagaoka Domain: They were bestowed the surname "Makino" by the lord of Nagaoka Domain the Makino clan which had grown from Kokujin (a governor of county) of Hoi County in Mikawa Province to Kinsei Daimyo (feudal lord of the Edo period).

sen.j: 清和源氏・源維義（松井冠者）を祖とする松井氏の一系統。
sen.e: It is the family line whose forefather was MINAMOTO no Koreyoshi (kaja MATSUI) from the Seiwa-Genji.
They were a branch of the Matsui clan that originated from MINAMOTO no Koreyoshi (Kanja MATSUI) of Seiwa-Genji.
They were a branch of the Matsui clan that originated from MINAMOTO no Koreyoshi (Kanja MATSUI) of Seiwa-Genji.

sen.j: 三河松井氏にも説明がある。
sen.e: This is explained in a later section on the "Mikawa Matsui clan."
This is explained in a later section on the "Mikawa Matsui clan."
This is explained in a later section on the "Mikawa Matsui clan."

sen.j: 京極家臣松井氏 ； 近世大名となった京極高次家などには、松井姓の家臣が散見される。
sen.e: The Matsui clan of the Kyogoku-family vassel; some vassals with the surname Matsui are seen in the genealogy of the Takatsugu KYOGOKU family, who became daimyo during the Kinsei period (between the Azu chi-Momoyama period and Edo period).
The Matsui clan as the vassals of the Kyogoku family: There found the Matsui clan that served as vassals of Kinsei Daimyo the Takatsugu KYOGOKU family.
sen.cmt: 用語の統一。わかりやすくしました。「近世大名」の説明は前段でしています。
sen.e: The Matsui clan as the vassals of the Kyogoku family: There found the Matsui clan that served as vassals of Kinsei Daimyo the Takatsugu KYOGOKU family.

sen.j: 清和源氏・源維義（松井冠者）を祖とする松井氏の一系統が近江国宇田源氏・佐々木氏の幕下層となっていた。
sen.e: The Matsui clan, whose forefather was MINAMOTO no Koreyoshi (kaja MATSUI) from Seiwa-Genji mostly occupied the positions of makushita (retainers of the shogun) of Sasaki clan of Uda Genji in Omi Province.
A branch of the Matsui clan, originated from MINAMOTO no Koreyoshi (Kanja MATSUI) of Seiwa-Genji, occupied the positions of retainers of the Sasaki clan of Uda-Genji in Omi Province.
sen.cmt: 用語の統一。わかりやすくしました。
sen.e: A branch of the Matsui clan, originated from MINAMOTO no Koreyoshi (Kanja MATSUI) of Seiwa-Genji, occupied the positions of retainers of the Sasaki clan of Uda-Genji in Omi Province.

sen.j: 近江源氏棟梁の佐々木氏が、家を分けて六角氏・京極氏となったが、室町時代に京極氏は有力な守護大名となった。
sen.e: The Sasaki clas was the toryo (head of the clan) of the Omi-Genji (Minamoto clan) but later split into the Rokkaku clan and Kyogoku clan; during the Muromachi period; the Kyogoku clan became dominant shugo daimyo (shugo were Japanese provincial military governors that became daimyo, which were Japanese feudal lords).

The Sasaki clan, the toryo (head of the clan) of the Omi-Genji (Minamoto clan), split into the Rokkaku clan and the Kyogoku clan, and in the Muromachi period, one of them, the Kyogoku clan became dominant Shugo Daimyo (provincial military governor).
sen.cmt: 用語の統一。わかりやすくしました。
sen.e: The Sasaki clan, the toryo (head of the clan) of the Omi-Genji (Minamoto clan), split into the Rokkaku clan and the Kyogoku clan, and in the Muromachi period, one of them, the Kyogoku clan became dominant Shugo Daimyo (provincial military governor).

sen.j: 応仁の乱後に家督争いなどで没落したが戦国時代を乗り切った京極氏の一系統が、佐々木氏以来の家臣・与騎の一部を組み込んで近世大名となり転封を繰り返した。
sen.e: The Matsui clan battled over the succession of the family estate after the Onin war and their power temporarily declined; however, one of the families of the Kyogoku clan survived the Sengoku period and incorporated some of the vassals and lower-ranking samurai warriors who served the Sasaki clan became daimyo during the Kinsei period, but their territory frequently changed.

After the Onin War, they declined for the conflicts over the succession; however, one branch of the Kyogoku clan survived the Sengoku period; they incorporated some of the vassals and lower-ranking samurai warriors who had served the Sasaki clan, and at last became Kinsei Daimyo; however, their domain was frequently changed by the order of the shogunate.
sen.cmt: 用語の統一。わかりやすくしました。
sen.e: After the Onin War, they declined for the conflicts over the succession; however, one branch of the Kyogoku clan survived the Sengoku period; they incorporated some of the vassals and lower-ranking samurai warriors who had served the Sasaki clan, and at last became Kinsei Daimyo; however, their domain was frequently changed by the order of the shogunate.

sen.j: また近江国に土着した松井氏もある。
sen.e: Some Matsui clans settled in Omi County.
Some Matsui clans settled in Omi Province.
Some Matsui clans settled in Omi Province.

sen.j: 伊勢神宮神官松井氏 ；
sen.e: The Matsui clan of Ise-Jingu-Shrine priest
The Shinto priest of Ise-jingu Shrine, Matsui clan
The Shinto priest of Ise-jingu Shrine, Matsui clan

sen.j: 九条家侍・松井氏 ； 五摂家・九条家 家臣の松井氏。
sen.e: The Matsui clan of the Kujo-family vassel; the Matsui clan of Gosekke (the five top Fujiwara families whose members were eligible for the positions of Sessho and Kanpaku), the Kujo family vassal

The Matsui clan as vassals of the Kujo family: They served as vassals of the Matsui clan which was one of Gosekke (the five top Fujiwara families whose members were eligible for the positions of Sessho and Kanpaku).

The Matsui clan as vassals of the Kujo family: They served as vassals of the Matsui clan which was one of Gosekke (the five top Fujiwara families whose members were eligible for the positions of Sessho and Kanpaku).

sen.j: 近衛家諸大夫・松井氏 ； 五摂家筆頭・近衛家 重臣の松井氏。
sen.e: The Matsui clan of KONOE-famly shodaibu; the Matsui clan who served as the vassals of the head of Gosekke, Konoe family
The Matsui clan as taifu (vassals) of the KONOE family: They served as vassals of the head of Gosekke, the Konoe family.
The Matsui clan as taifu (vassals) of the KONOE family: They served as vassals of the head of Gosekke, the Konoe family.

sen.j: 小田原藩士松井氏 ； 相模国小田原藩主大久保氏家臣の松井氏は、書家として著名。
sen.e: The Matsui clan of the Odawara-Domain retainer; the Matsui clan who served as the vassals of the Okubo clan, the lord of Odawara Domain in Sagami Province are well known as calligraphers
The Matsui clan as the retainer of the Odawara Domain: They served as vassals of the Okubo clan, the lord of the Odawara Domain in Sagami Province and have been known as calligraphers.
The Matsui clan as the retainer of the Odawara Domain: They served as vassals of the Okubo clan, the lord of the Odawara Domain in Sagami Province and have been known as calligraphers.

sen.j: 諏訪藩重臣松井氏 ； 信濃国諏訪藩・諏訪氏の重臣
sen.e: The Matsui clan of Suwa-Domain senior vassal; the vassal of Suwa clan in the Suwa Domain in Shinano Province.
The Matsui clan as senior vassals of the Suwa Domain: They served as vassals of the Suwa clan of the Suwa Domain in Shinano Province.
The Matsui clan as senior vassals of the Suwa Domain: They served as vassals of the Suwa clan of the Suwa Domain in Shinano Province.

sen.j: 松江藩儒臣松井氏 ；
sen.e: The Matsui clan of Matsue-Domain Confucian vassal;
The Matsui clan as Confucian vassals of the Matsue Domain
The Matsui clan as Confucian vassals of the Matsue Domain

sen.j: 亀山藩重臣松井氏 ；
sen.e: The Matsui clan of Kameyama-Domain Confucian vassal;
The Matsui clan as senior vassals of the Kameyama Domain
The Matsui clan as senior vassals of the Kameyama Domain

sen.j: 三上藩重臣松井氏 ；
sen.e: The Matsui clan of Mikami-Domain senior vassal;
The Matsui clan as senior vassals of the Mikami Domain
The Matsui clan as senior vassals of the Mikami Domain

sen.j: 津和野藩重臣松井氏 ； 美作国津和野藩主亀井氏重臣の松井氏
sen.e: The Matsui clan of Tsuwano-Domain senior vassal; the Matsui clan who served as the senior vassal of Tsuwano-Domain in the Mimasaka Province
The Matsui clan as senior vassals of the Tsuwano Domain: They served as senior vassals of the Kamei clan, the lord of the Tsuwano Domain in Mimasaka Province.
The Matsui clan as senior vassals of the Tsuwano Domain: They served as senior vassals of the Kamei clan, the lord of the Tsuwano Domain in Mimasaka Province.

sen.j: 桂昌院侍女松井氏 ； 桂昌院の側近として権勢を振るった侍女の松井は、養子を迎えて幕臣・旗本に列した。
sen.e: The Matsui clan of Keisho-in's waiting maid; the Matsumoto clan who served as the waiting maid worked as the close adviser of Keisho-in; the clan adopted children and was raised to the Shogun's retainer and hatamoto (direct retainers of the bakufu, which is a form of Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

The Matsui clan as Jijo (maid) of Keishoin: "Matsui," a Jijo of Keishoin, played very important roles as a close adviser of Keishoin, and adopted children who later became the Shogun's retainer and Hatamoto (direct retainers of the shogunate).
sen.cmt: わかりやすくしました。
sen.e: The Matsui clan as Jijo (maid) of Keishoin: "Matsui," a Jijo of Keishoin, played very important roles as a close adviser of Keishoin, and adopted children who later became the Shogun's retainer and Hatamoto (direct retainers of the shogunate).

tit.j: 松井氏（清和源氏為義流）
tit.e: The Matsui clan (Tameyoshi line originated from the Seiwa-Genji)
The Matsui clan (Tameyoshi line of Seiwa-Genji)
The Matsui clan (Tameyoshi line of Seiwa-Genji)

sen.j: その祖は、清和源氏の源為義の子・源維義。
sen.e: The forefather was MINAMOTO no Koreyoshi, a son of MINAMOTO no Tameyoshi
The forefather was MINAMOTO no Koreyoshi, a son of MINAMOTO no Tameyoshi
The forefather was MINAMOTO no Koreyoshi, a son of MINAMOTO no Tameyoshi

sen.j: 維義が松井冠者を称したことから、維義の子の源義宗が松井の姓を名乗ったとする。
sen.e: It is said that after MINAMOTO no Koreyoshi called himself Kanja MATSUI, his son MINAMOTO no Yoshimune used the surname Matsui.
It is said that after MINAMOTO no Koreyoshi called himself Kanja MATSUI, his son MINAMOTO no Yoshimune used the surname Matsui.
It is said that after MINAMOTO no Koreyoshi called himself Kanja MATSUI, his son MINAMOTO no Yoshimune used the surname Matsui.

sen.j: 同じ清和源氏出身で別流に三河松井氏、丹波松井氏、遠江松井氏、近江松井氏がある。
sen.e: Other families of the same clan included the Mikawa Matsui clan, Tanba Matsui clan, Totomi Matsui clan, and Omi Matsui clan.
Other families of the same clan included the Mikawa Matsui clan, Tanba Matsui clan, Totomi Matsui clan, and Omi Matsui clan.
Other families of the same clan included the Mikawa Matsui clan, Tanba Matsui clan, Totomi Matsui clan, and Omi Matsui clan.

tit.e: The Mikawa Matsui clan
The Mikawa Matsui clan
The Mikawa Matsui clan

sen.j: 三河国に入り、吉良氏の家臣となった系統がある。
sen.e: One of the Matsui families became the vassal of the Kira clan of the Mikawa County.
One of the Matsui families became the vassal of the Kira clan of Mikawa Province.
One of the Matsui families became the vassal of the Kira clan of Mikawa Province.

sen.j: これが三河松井氏である。
sen.e: This family has been called the Mikawa Matsui clan.
This family has been called the Mikawa Matsui clan.
This family has been called the Mikawa Matsui clan.

sen.j: 松井忠次の代で徳川家康に従い、松平姓を受けて松平周防守康親と名乗った。
sen.e: The Matsui clan subordinated themselves during the time of Tadatsugu MATSUI; Tadatsugu was bestowed the Matsudaira cognomen and used the name Yasuchika Suonokami MATSUDAIRA.
Tadatsugu MATSUI first served Ieyasu TOKUGAWA, and later he was given the surname "Matsudaira" and called himself Yasuchika Suo-no-kami MATSUDAIRA.
Tadatsugu MATSUI first served Ieyasu TOKUGAWA, and later he was given the surname "Matsudaira" and called himself Yasuchika Suo-no-kami MATSUDAIRA.

sen.j: これ以降、松平姓を受けた一族を松井松平家とも呼ぶ。
sen.e: Since then, his family has been called the Matsui Matsudaira family.
Since then, his family has been called the Matsui Matsudaira family.
Since then, his family has been called the Matsui Matsudaira family.

sen.j: 譜代大名や旗本を出した。
sen.e: The Matsui Matsudaira family produced fudai daimyo (a daimyo hereditary vassal to the Tokugawa family) and hatamoto.
The Matsui Matsudaira family produced fudai daimyo (a daimyo hereditary vassal to the Tokugawa family) and hatamoto.
The Matsui Matsudaira family produced fudai daimyo (a daimyo hereditary vassal to the Tokugawa family) and hatamoto.

sen.j: 特に大名の家は江戸時代に繁栄し、国政の中枢に座り、幕閣の老中・大坂城代・京都所司代・寺社奉行などを歴任した。
sen.e: Particularly, the Matsui clan who served as daimyo prospered during the Edo period, and took the central role in the administration of state affairs; they successively assumed various positions such as Roju (member of shogun's council of elders) of the cabinet officials of the Shogunate, Osaka Jodai (the keeper of Osaka-jo Castle), Kyoto Shoshidai (Kyoto deputy), and Jisha-bugyo (magistrate of temples and shrines).

Particularly, the Matsui clan who served as daimyo prospered during the Edo period, and took the central role in the administration of state affairs; they successively assumed various positions such as Roju (member of shogun's council of elders) of the cabinet officials of the Shogunate, Osaka Jodai (the keeper of Osaka-jo Castle), Kyoto Shoshidai (Kyoto deputy), and Jisha-bugyo (magistrate of temples and shrines).

Particularly, the Matsui clan who served as daimyo prospered during the Edo period, and took the central role in the administration of state affairs; they successively assumed various positions such as Roju (member of shogun's council of elders) of the cabinet officials of the Shogunate, Osaka Jodai (the keeper of Osaka-jo Castle), Kyoto Shoshidai (Kyoto deputy), and Jisha-bugyo (magistrate of temples and shrines).

tit.e: The Matsui clan of the lord of the Yatsushiro-jo Castle
The lord of the Yatsushiro-jo Castle, Matsui clan
The lord of the Yatsushiro-jo Castle, Matsui clan

tit.j: 幕臣から細川氏の家老へ
tit.e: From shogun's retainer to Karo (chief retainer)
From shogun's retainer to Karo (chief retainer)
From shogun's retainer to Karo (chief retainer)

sen.j: 室町時代には、足利将軍家に仕える幕臣であった。
sen.e: During the Muromachi period, the Matsui clan served as the Shogun's retainer of Ashikaga Shogun family.
During the Muromachi period, the Matsui clan served as the Shogun's retainer of Ashikaga Shogun family.
During the Muromachi period, the Matsui clan served as the Shogun's retainer of Ashikaga Shogun family.

sen.j: 足利義輝が永禄の変（永禄8年・1565年）で殺害されると、松井正之の子松井康之は、同じく足利将軍家に仕えていた細川幽斎（幽斎）と共に、義輝の弟・足利義昭を将軍に擁立するために行動する。
sen.e: When Yoshiteru ASHIKAGA was killed in the Eiroku Incident (1565), a son of Masayuki MATSUI, Yasuyuki MATSUI, took action with Yusai HOSOKAWA to back up Yoshiaki ASHIKAGA, the younger brother of Yoshiteru, to make him the next shogun.

When Yoshiteru ASHIKAGA was killed in the Eiroku Incident (1565), a son of Masayuki MATSUI, Yasuyuki MATSUI, took action with Yusai HOSOKAWA to back up Yoshiaki ASHIKAGA, the younger brother of Yoshiteru, to make him the next shogun.

When Yoshiteru ASHIKAGA was killed in the Eiroku Incident (1565), a son of Masayuki MATSUI, Yasuyuki MATSUI, took action with Yusai HOSOKAWA to back up Yoshiaki ASHIKAGA, the younger brother of Yoshiteru, to make him the next shogun.

sen.j: 康之は、義昭が尾張・美濃の大名・織田信長を頼ったときにその宿所を訪れ、やがて藤孝の下で働くようになる。
sen.e: When Yasuyuki seeked for assistance from Nobunaga ODA, a daimyo of Owari and Mino counties, he stayed at accommodations in these counties and began to serve under Fujitaka HOSOKAWA.
When Yoshiaki asked assistance from Nobunaga ODA who was a daimyo of Owari Province and Mino Province, Yasuyuki went to his temporal residence and began to serve Fujitaka HOSOKAWA.
When Yoshiaki asked assistance from Nobunaga ODA who was a daimyo of Owari Province and Mino Province, Yasuyuki went to his temporal residence and began to serve Fujitaka HOSOKAWA.

sen.j: 藤孝の子・細川忠興と明智光秀の娘・玉（細川ガラシャ）の婚礼における玉姫輿入請取役は康之が行っている。
sen.e: Yasuyuki played the role as an undertaker of Princess Tama's wedding carriage at the wedding of Tadaoki HOSOKAWA, the son of Fujitaka, and Tama (Gracia HOSOKAWA), the daughter of Mitsuhide AKECHI.
sen.cmt: 「玉姫輿入請取役」の訳不明。「the role as an undertaker of Princess Tama's wedding carriage としました。
sen.e: At the wedding between Tadaoki HOSOKAWA (a son of Fujitaka) and Princess Tama (Gracia HOSOKAWA, a daughter of Mitsuhide AKECHI), Yasuyuki served as the organizer for Tama.
At the wedding between Tadaoki HOSOKAWA (a son of Fujitaka) and Princess Tama (Gracia HOSOKAWA, a daughter of Mitsuhide AKECHI), Yasuyuki served as the organizer for Tama.

sen.j: 信長の下で細川氏は丹後国の領主となり、康之は丹後国松倉城を任せられた。
sen.e: Under Nobunaga's government, the Hosokawa clan became the feudal lord of Tango Province and Yasuyuki was assigned the Matsukura-jo Castle.
Under Nobunaga's government, the Hosokawa clan became the feudal lord of Tango Province and Yasuyuki was assigned the Matsukura-jo Castle.
Under Nobunaga's government, the Hosokawa clan became the feudal lord of Tango Province and Yasuyuki was assigned the Matsukura-jo Castle.

sen.j: 生涯五十余度の合戦に出陣し、武功高く、石田三成の家老・島左近や上杉景勝の家老・直江兼続らと並ぶ名家老といわれる。
sen.e: Thoughout his life, Yasuyuki went into approximatly 50 battles and is said to have both achieved brilliant military exploits and been one of the most excellent Karo, along with Sakon SHIMA, who worked for Mitsunari ISHIDA and Kanetsugu NAOE, who worked for Kagekatsu UESUGI.

Thoughout his life, Yasuyuki went into over than fifty battles and made brilliant achievements; and it has been said that he was one of the most excellent Karo (chief retainer), along with Sakon SHIMA who worked for Mitsunari ISHIDA and Kanetsugu NAOE who worked for Kagekatsu UESUGI.

Thoughout his life, Yasuyuki engaged in over fifty battles and made brilliant achievements; and it has been said that he was one of the most excellent Karo (chief retainer), along with Sakon SHIMA who worked for Mitsunari ISHIDA and Kanetsugu NAOE who worked for Kagekatsu UESUGI.

sen.j: 康之の働きぶりをみた豊臣秀吉は石見国半国18万石を与えると申し出たが、康之は細川家に仕えることを希望して辞退した。
sen.e: Impressed with Yasuyuki's work, Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI proposed to offer half of the Iwami Province, 10,000 koku to him; however, Yasuyuki prefered to serve the Hosokawa clan and declined this offer.

Impressed with Yasuyuki's work, Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI tried to headhunt offering a half of Iwami Province and rice stipend 180,000 koku (32470.2 cubic meters), however, Yasuyuki declined it and kept serving the Hosokawa clan.
sen.cmt: スペル。数字間違い。用語の統一。
sen.e: Impressed with Yasuyuki's work, Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI tried to headhunt offering a half of Iwami Province and rice stipend 180,000 koku (32470.2 cubic meters), however, Yasuyuki declined it and kept serving the Hosokawa clan.

sen.j: 秀吉は、康之が信長から拝領していた山城国相楽郡神童寺村及び愛宕郡八瀬村の知行安堵の朱印状に「深山」という茶壺を添えて贈る。
sen.e: Hideyoshi gave a cha-tsubo (tea urn) called 'Miyama' to Yasuyuki as a gift along with a shuinjo (a vermillion seal letter) to secure the fief Yasuyuki was bestowed from Nobunaga, including Jindoji Village in Sagara County, Yamashiro Province and Yase Village in Atago County.

Hideyoshi gave a cha-tsubo (tea urn) called 'Miyama' to Yasuyuki as a gift along with a shuinjo (a vermillion seal letter) to secure the fief Yasuyuki was bestowed from Nobunaga, including Jindoji Village in Sagara County, Yamashiro Province and Yase Village in Atago County.

Hideyoshi gave a cha-tsubo (tea urn) called 'Miyama' to Yasuyuki as a gift along with a shuinjo (a vermillion seal letter) to secure the fief Yasuyuki was bestowed from Nobunaga, including Jindoji Village in Sagara County, Yamashiro Province and Yase Village in Atago County.

sen.j: この茶壺は、後世十八万石の壺と呼ばれる。
sen.e: This chatsubo came to be called 160,000 koku tsubo (urn) in later years.
This chatsubo was later called "180,000 koku tsubo."
This chatsubo was later called "180,000 koku tsubo."

sen.j: 慶長5年（1600年）の関ヶ原の戦いには、康之とその子・松井興長は藩主細川忠興に従って戦い、徳川方の勝利に貢献した。
sen.e: During the Battle of Sekigahara, Yasuyuki and his son Okinaga MATSUI obeyed the lord Tadaoki HOSOKAWA and participated in the war which contributed to the victory of the Tokugawa side.
In the Battle of Sekigahara, Yasuyuki and his son Okinaga MATSUI fought under their lord Tadaoki HOSOKAWA and contributed to the victory of the Tokugawa side.
sen.cmt: わかりやすくしました。
sen.e: In the Battle of Sekigahara, Yasuyuki and his son Okinaga MATSUI fought under their lord Tadaoki HOSOKAWA and contributed to the victory of the Tokugawa side.

sen.j: 戦後、細川家は豊前国・豊後国（現在の福岡県と大分県の一部）39万石余りの大名となり、康之は豊後国木付（杵築）城を任せられて2万5千石の領地が与えられた。
sen.e: After the war, the Hosokawa family became daimyo of 39,000 koku in the territories of the Buzen Province and Bungo Province (a part of present day Fukuoka prefecture and Oita Prefecture); Yasuyuki was assigned the Kitsuki-jo Castle in Bungo Province and was bestowed a territory of 25,000 koku.

After the war, the Hosokawa family became one of powerful daimyo with more than 390,000 koku of the Buzen Province and Bungo Province (a part of present Fukuoka Prefecture and Oita Prefecture); Yasuyuki was assigned the Kitsuki-jo Castle in Bungo Province and was bestowed fief of 25,000 koku.
sen.cmt: 数字間違い。用語の統一。
sen.e: After the war, the Hosokawa family became one of powerful daimyo with more than 390,000 koku of the Buzen Province and Bungo Province (a part of present Fukuoka Prefecture and Oita Prefecture); Yasuyuki was assigned the Kitsuki-jo Castle in Bungo Province and was bestowed fief of 25,000 koku.

sen.j: 興長は康之の次男として天正10年（1582年）に生まれ、慶長16年（1611年）康之が隠居すると家督を相続した。
sen.e: Okinaga was born in 1582 as the second son of Yasuyuki; after his father's retirement, Okinaga succeeded the family headship.
Okinaga was born in 1582 as the second son of Yasuyuki; after his father's retirement in 1611, Okinaga succeeded the family headship.
Okinaga was born in 1582 as the second son of Yasuyuki; after his father's retirement in 1611, Okinaga succeeded the family headship.

sen.j: 寛永9年（1632年）細川家が豊前・豊後から肥後国熊本藩に国替になると、興長には玉名・合志郡に3万石が与えられた。
sen.e: When the Hosokawa clan transferred domains from Buzen Province and Bungo Province to Kumamoto Domain, Higo Province, Okinaga was awarded 30,000 koku for his territories, the Tamana County and Koshi County.

In 1632 when the Hosokawa clan was transferred from Buzen Province and Bungo Province to the Kumamoto Domain of Higo Province by the order of the shogunate, Okinaga was given 30,000 koku of Tamana County and Koshi County.
sen.cmt: わかりやすくしました
sen.e: In 1632 when the Hosokawa clan was transferred from Buzen Province and Bungo Province to the Kumamoto Domain of Higo Province by the order of the shogunate, Okinaga was given 30,000 koku of Tamana County and Koshi County.

tit.e: The lord of Yatsushiro-jo Castle in Higo Province
The lord of Yatsushiro-jo Castle in Higo Province
The lord of Yatsushiro-jo Castle in Higo Province

sen.j: 藩主・細川忠利の父である忠興が隠居城とした肥後八代城は薩摩の島津氏に対する押さえの役割を持ち、特に一国一城令の例外とされていたが、正保3年（1646年）には興長が八代城を預かることになり、以後代々松井家が八代城代を務めた。
sen.e: After his retirement, Tadaoki HOSOKAWA, the father of the lord Tadatoshi HOSOKAWA, resided in the Yatsushiro-jo Castle; the castle functioned as the barrier that prevented the invasion of the Shimazu clan and was thought as an exceptional case of the Ikkoku Ichijo Rei (Law of One Castle per Province); however, Okinaga MATSUI was ordered to be in charge of this castle in 1646, and from then on, the Matsuki clan served as the chamberlain at the castle.

After his retirement, Tadaoki HOSOKAWA, the father of the lord Tadatoshi HOSOKAWA, resided in the Yatsushiro-jo Castle; since the castle functioned as the barrier that prevented the invasion of the Shimazu clan, it was regarded as an exception of the Ikkoku Ichijo Law (according to it, one province can keep only one castle); in 1646, Okinaga MATSUI was ordered to retain this castle, and from then on, the Matsuki clan served as Jodai (keeper of castle).
sen.cmt: わかりやすくしました。
sen.e: After his retirement, Tadaoki HOSOKAWA, the father of the lord Tadatoshi HOSOKAWA, resided in the Yatsushiro-jo Castle; since the castle functioned as the barrier that prevented the invasion of the Shimazu clan, it was regarded as an exception of the Ikkoku Ichijo Law (according to it, one province can keep only one castle); in 1646, Okinaga MATSUI was ordered to retain this castle, and from then on, the Matsuki clan served as a keeper of Yatsushiro-jo Castle.
sen.cmt: served as Jodai (keeper of castle)→served as a keeper of Yatsushiro-jo Castle.

sen.j: 興長は細川忠興の娘古保を妻とし、また忠興の六男を養嗣子に迎え（松井寄之）、細川別姓である長岡姓を賜り長岡佐渡守と称した。
sen.e: Okinaga took Tadaoki HOSOKAWA's daughter, Ko, as his wife, and Tadaoki's sixth son as his adopted heir (Yoriyuki MATSUI); furthermore, he was bestowed another family name, Nagaoka, and used the name Nagaoka-Sado-no-kami.

Okinaga married Tadaoki HOSOKAWA's daughter Koho, and adopted Tadaoki's sixth son as his adopted heir (Yoriyuki MATSUI); he was bestowed the new surname "Nagaoka" which was another family name of the Hosokawa clan, and called himself "Nagaoka Sado-no-kami."
sen.cmt: 誤訳。わかりやすくしました。
sen.e: Okinaga married Tadaoki HOSOKAWA's daughter Koho, and adopted Tadaoki's sixth son as his adopted heir (Yoriyuki MATSUI); he was bestowed the new surname "Nagaoka" which was another family name of the Hosokawa clan, and called himself "Nagaoka Sado-no-kami."

sen.j: 松井家は、宮本武蔵が細川家に仕官する直前に興長に宛てた書状（長岡佐渡守宛書状）が残るなど武蔵と親交が深かった。
sen.e: The Matsui clan had such a close relationship with Musashi MIYAMOTO that Musashi's letter (letter written to Sadoku) sent to Okinaga just before becaming an officer of the Hosokawa clan was found in their house.

The Matsui clan had a close relationship with Musashi MIYAMOTO, and there remains Musashi's letter to Okinaga ("the Letter to Nagaoka Sado-no-kami") which was written immediate before Musashi began to serve the Hosokawa clan.
sen.cmt: わかりやすくしました。
sen.e: The Matsui clan had a close relationship with Musashi MIYAMOTO, and there remains Musashi's letter to Okinaga ("the Letter to Nagaoka Sado-no-kami") which was written immediate before Musashi began to serve the Hosokawa clan.

sen.j: 寄之は熊本藩の客将となった宮本武蔵を後見し、兵法では武蔵の弟子となった。
sen.e: Yoriyuki acted as guardian of Musashi MIYAMOTO, who became Kyakusho (extra shogun) of the Kumamoto domain yet he learned art of warfare as his disciple.
Yoriyuki became the guardian of Musashi MIYAMOTO who became a guest samurai of the Kumamoto Domain, and he learned art of warfare as Musashi's direct disciple.
sen.cmt: わかりやすくしました。
sen.e: Yoriyuki became the guardian of Musashi MIYAMOTO who became a guest samurai of the Kumamoto Domain, and he learned art of warfare as Musashi's direct disciple.

sen.j: 寄之は、病身の武蔵の世話をし、武蔵の養子である宮本伊織と書状のやりとりをするなど、武蔵と深く関わった。
sen.e: Yoriyuki had a close relationship with Musashi taking care of him during Musashi's illness and corresponded with Musashi's adopted son, Iori MIYAMOTO.
Yoriyuki maintained a close relationship with Musashi taking care of him during Musashi's illness and corresponded with Musashi's adopted son Iori MIYAMOTO.
Yoriyuki maintained a close relationship with Musashi taking care of him during Musashi's illness and corresponded with Musashi's adopted son Iori MIYAMOTO.

sen.j: そのため、水墨画や工芸品など多くの武蔵ゆかりの品々が現在も松井家に伝えられている。
sen.e: Therefore, many items that belonged to Musashi, such as ink-wash paintings and artifacts, are still preserved in the Matsui clan.
Therefore, many Musashi's works including ink-wash paintings and artifacts are still preserved in the Matsui family.
sen.cmt: 「ゆかり」はこの場合武蔵の作品。わかりやすくしました。
sen.e: Therefore, many Musashi's works including ink-wash paintings and artifacts are still preserved in the Matsui family.

sen.j: 秀吉から与えられた山城国の領地は徳川幕府の下でも維持されており、松井家は徳川幕府の直臣・陪臣の性格を併せ持つ特殊な家であった。
sen.e: The Matsui clan's territory in the Yamashiro County given by Hideyoshi was maintained during the Tokugawa shogunate and the Mastsui clan acted in a special position, serving both as a great vassal and baishin (indirect vassal).

Since during the period of the Tokugawa shogunate the Matsui family had been maintaining their possession in Yamashiro Province which had been given by Hideyoshi before the period of the Tokugawa, it can be said that the Matsui family was a rare family which kept the status of direct vassal of the Tokugawa shogunate as well as the status of indirect vassal at the same time.
sen.cmt: わかりやすくしました。
sen.e: Since during the period of the Tokugawa shogunate the Matsui family had been maintaining their possession in Yamashiro Province which had been given by Hideyoshi before the period of the Tokugawa, it can be said that the Matsui family was a rare family which kept the status of direct vassal of the Tokugawa shogunate as well as the status of indirect vassal at the same time.

sen.j: 毎年の参勤交代こそしないものの、松井家当主および徳川将軍の代替わりに際しては江戸に出府して将軍に拝謁した。
sen.e: The Matsui clan did not participate in Sankinkotai (a system under which feudal lords in the Edo period were required to spend every other year in residence in Edo), however, at the time when the shogunate position was taken over, they were obliged to fulfill this responsibility.

Therefore, they escaped Sankinkotai (a system under which feudal lords in the Edo period were required to spend every other year in residence in Edo), however, at the succession of shogun and their own succession, they were obliged to go to Edo and meet the shogun.
sen.cmt: わかりやすくしました。
sen.e: They were therefore exempt from the Sankinkotai (a system under which feudal lords in the Edo period were required to spend every other year in residence in Edo); however, they were obliged to go to Edo and meet the shogun on the accession of a new head of the Matsui family or a new Tokugawa shogun.

sen.j: 松井家は細川血族として明治維新まで代々筆頭家老を勤めることになる。
sen.e: As a blood relation of the Hosokawa clan, the Matsui clan continued to serve as Hittokaro (the head of chief retainers) until the Meiji period.
As a blood relation of the Hosokawa clan, the Matsui clan continued to serve as Hittokaro (the head of chief retainers) until the Meiji Restoration.
As a blood relation of the Hosokawa clan, the Matsui clan continued to serve as Hittokaro (the head of chief retainers) until the Meiji Restoration.

sen.j: 松井氏は細川家臣でありながら、実質上の肥後八代支藩3万石の大名格藩主であった。
sen.e: The Matsui clan was the retainer for the Hosokawa family, however, they were the branch-domain lord, who equalled to daimyo, in charge of 30,000 koku of the Yatsushiro branchi Domain in Higo Province.

Although the Matsui clan was one of retainers of the Hosokawa family, they were regarded as a domain lord almost equal to daimyo, since they practically ruled vast land of 30.000 koku of Yatsushiro Domain in Higo Province.
sen.cmt: わかりやすくしました
sen.e: Although the Matsui clan was one of retainers of the Hosokawa family, they were regarded as a domain lord almost equal to daimyo, since they practically ruled vast land of 30.000 koku of Yatsushiro Domain in Higo Province.

sen.j: なお、熊本藩（細川氏）においては、世襲家老家の松井氏・米田氏・有吉氏を上卿三家と呼んだ。
sen.e: In Kumamoto Domain (the Hosokawa clan), three hereditary Karo family, including the Matsui clan, the Yoneda clan and the Ariyoshi clan, were called the three families of shokei (the top court officials).
In Kumamoto Domain (the Hosokawa clan), three hereditary Karo family, including the Matsui clan, the Yoneda clan and the Ariyoshi clan, were called "Jokei Sanke" (three noble families).
sen.cmt: 誤訳。わかりやすくしました。
sen.e: In Kumamoto Domain (the Hosokawa clan), three hereditary Karo family, including the Matsui clan, the Yoneda clan and the Ariyoshi clan, were called "Jokei Sanke" (three noble families).

tit.e: Historical materials and historic sites
Historical materials and historic sites
Historical materials and historic sites

sen.j: 松井家の城下町であった熊本県八代市の八代市立博物館や松井文庫には松井歴代史料が展示されており、近くには八代城跡や松井家の御茶屋だった松浜軒（しょうひんけん）もある。
sen.e: In Yatsushiro City of Kumamoto Prefecture, former castle town of the Matsui clan, historical materials of the Matsui clan are displayed at the Yatsushiro Municipal Museum and Matsui Bunko library; in this area, sites of Yatsushiro-jo Castle and Shohinken, which used to be Matsui clan's ochaya (rest house) also remain.

In Yatsushiro City of Kumamoto Prefecture which had been the castle town of the Matsui clan, historical materials of the Matsui clan are displayed at the Yatsushiro Municipal Museum and Matsui Bunko Library, and in its vicinity, there remain sites of Yatsushiro-jo Castle and Shohinken which used to be Matsui clan's ochaya (rest house).
sen.cmt: わかりやすくしました。
sen.e: In Yatsushiro City of Kumamoto Prefecture which had been the castle town of the Matsui clan, historical materials of the Matsui clan are displayed at the Yatsushiro Municipal Museum and Matsui Bunko Library, and in its vicinity, there remain sites of Yatsushiro-jo Castle and Shohinken which used to be Matsui clan's ochaya (rest house).

sen.j: 松井家系図等の史料は八代市立博物館「未来の森ミュージアム」などのウェブでも見ることができる。
sen.e: Historical materials of the Matsui clan, such as their genealogy, are also available from the website of 'Yatsushiro Municipal Museum.'
Historical materials of the Matsui clan, such as their genealogy, can be seen on the website of 'Yatsushiro Municipal Museum' and so on.
Historical materials of the Matsui clan, such as their genealogy, can be seen on the website of 'Yatsushiro Municipal Museum' and so on.

sen.j: なお熊本市の水前寺成趣園内にある出水神社にも史料がある。
sen.e: The clan's historical materials are also accessible at the Izumi-jinja Shrine in the Suizenji Joju-en Garden in Kumamoto City.
The clan's historical materials are also accessible at the Izumi-jinja Shrine in the Suizenji Joju-en Garden in Kumamoto City.
The clan's historical materials are also accessible at the Izumi-jinja Shrine in the Suizenji Joju-en Garden in Kumamoto City.
